00-General/00-Roadmap.title: 00-Roadmap
00-General/00-Roadmap.content:
This roadmap outlines our shared journey through Machine Learning. It is designed to be hands-on, collaborative, and flexible â€” grounded in strong resources like Hands-On ML, curated online courses, and practical exercises. Each topic links to its own folder containing resources, code, notes, and tasks. Weâ€™re building this not just to learn individually, but to grow as a team, help each other, and possibly build something great together.

00-General/01-Project-Structure.title: 01-Project Structure
00-General/01-Project-Structure.content:
ğŸ—‚ï¸ Repository Structure Overview
This is a collaborative Obsidian vault for learning and documenting Machine Learning topics, projects, and resources. Below is a breakdown of the folder structure and its purpose.

ğŸ“ 00-General
General notes about the project:

Roadmap
Repo structure (this file)
Contribution guidelines


ğŸ“ 01-Topics
The core learning material â€” structured by topic.
Each topic (e.g., 01-Math-Foundation) contains:

01-Overview.md â€” high-level summary
02-Resources.md â€” links to articles, books, videos
03-CodeExamples/ â€” demos, notebooks
04-Notes.md â€” detailed explanations
05-Exercises.md â€” practice problems


ğŸ“ 02-Papers
Summaries, notes, and insights from academic papers related to:

Machine learning theory
LLMs and NLP
Novel techniques and models


ğŸ“ 03-Projects
Hands-on applications of ML concepts:

Mini-projects and capstones
Experiments and implementations
Group or individual work


ğŸ“ 04-Meetings
Meeting notes and logs:

Weekly planning
Discussion summaries
Task tracking and next steps


ğŸ“ 05-Templates
Reusable content blocks and templates for:

Meetings
Topic overviews
Paper reviews
Project submissions


ğŸ“ 06-CheatSheets
Quick reference guides:

Syntax snippets
ML workflows
Math formulas
Command-line cheats


ğŸ“ 07-Resources
Useful external resources not tied to a specific topic.
ğŸ“‚ Datasets
Links and notes about datasets:

Public datasets
Usage examples
Licensing info

ğŸ“‚ Tools
Curated ML tools:

Libraries (e.g., scikit-learn, PyTorch)
Platforms (e.g., HuggingFace, Weights & Biases)
Utilities (e.g., label studio, Colab)

00-General/02-Contributing-Guidelines.title: 02-Contributing Guidelines
00-General/02-Contributing-Guidelines.content:
ğŸ’¾ General Workflow

Pull before editing
Push after committing
One person = one personal notes file (e.g., Notes-JohnDoe.md)
Shared files like Overview.md â†’ edit only if youâ€™ve pulled recently and no one else is working on it
Do NOT change the folder structure without notice

ğŸ§  Ownership





















File TypeWho Can EditNotes-Name.mdThe owner onlyOverview.mdAgreed uponOther FilesAnyone (coordinate via Telegram or Issues)
ğŸ›  Tools

Use Obsidian Git plugin or GitHub Desktop
Keep commit messages clear: â€œAdd summary for CNNsâ€, not â€œUpdateâ€

ğŸ’¥ Conflicts

If conflict occurs, ping someone experienced or back up your changes

04-Meetings/1404-04-20.content:
Date: 1404-04-20
Time:  10:00 PM to 12:00 AM
Facilitator: Mehrdad

ğŸ“Œ Agenda

 Opening remarks
 Intro of ML and learning group goals
 Reflections on .NET experience
 Format discussion: books, courses, roles
 Repository structure and workflow
 Team contributions and responsibilities
 Next steps and summary


ğŸ“ Notes & Discussion
ğŸ”° Intro & Philosophy

The ML group is about learning together, not because we have to, but because it makes it better.
Key benefits:

More consistent learning
Social and intellectual motivation
Opportunity for future collaborations




ğŸ’­ Reflection on .NET

.NET started strong but had challenges:

Initial teacher-led format added pressure
Group expectations sometimes created imbalance
Voluntary group â‰  forced workload


Positive outcomes:

Successfully finished most topics
Learned about coordination and project dynamics




ğŸ“š How to Handle ML
Formats considered:

Watching a course together
Reading a book collectively
Taking turns explaining topics
Doing small projects
Weekly sync-up meetings

Agreed on:

Less pressure, more sharing
Some members can curate content
Use GitHub repo with rules + branches
Encourage multiple contributors, not single leaders


âš™ï¸ Roles and Team

People may contribute based on time and interest
Need 2â€“3 active curators or maintainers
Consider forming a lightweight team for structure


ğŸ“– Courses and Books

Decision pending on:

Primary source (book vs course)
Structure of progression




ğŸ›  Obsidian + GitHub Setup

Showed vault with:

Topics
Roadmap
Meeting structure
Templates


Emphasis on clean structure and contribution model


âœ… Decisions

Start with Roadmap + weekly sync
Contribute resources collaboratively
GitHub will be used for shared content
Obsidian as knowledge base
Keep the group lean and agile (for now)


Tasks

05-Templates/Paper-Template.title: Paper Template
05-Templates/Paper-Template.content:
BERT: Pre-training of Deep Bidirectional Transformers for Language Understanding
ğŸ“Œ Summary
BERT introduces a masked language model and next sentence prediction for pre-training. Key innovation is bidirectional context.
ğŸ“ƒ Citation
Devlin et al., 2018 â€“ arxiv.org/abs/1810.04805
ğŸ§  Key Ideas

Masked Language Modeling (MLM)
Next Sentence Prediction (NSP)
Fine-tuning on downstream tasks

ğŸ” Whatâ€™s New?

Bidirectionality in pretraining
Outperformed SOTA on GLUE, SQuAD

ğŸ’¬ Discussion

Why MLM instead of traditional LM?
Do we still need NSP today?

ğŸ‘¥ Notes by Group

Mehrdadâ€™s Notes
